markdown.markdown:
```{r setup, echo=FALSE,warning=FALSE,message=FALSE} knitr::opts_knit$set(root.dir = rprojroot::find_root(".git/index")) ## relative to the project root include_local_graphics <- function(x) { knitr::include_graphics(here::here(x)) } ``` # Breaking the Laws of Health Geography {#title}

EPID 594 2/3/2022

Jon Zelner `jzelner@umich.edu` [`epibayes.io`](https://epibayes.io)

# Agenda >- Final project timeline >- Discussing the laws of health geography >- Hands-on smoothing activity # Final Project >- Final form of your project is up to you. >- Please feel free to continue with your 592 topic if that is of interest! >- Weekly project checkpoints are there to make sure you are able to make progress in the (limited) time we have. >- Ultimately, I want you to do what is most useful and interesting for you. # The "First Law" of Geography {.quote .center} # {background-iframe="https://www.youtube.com/embed/kRsF9S8JqBI?autoplay=1"} # Why is the first law useful? {.quote .center} # "A world of white noise" {.imgslide} "White noise" has lots of variation with little autocorrelation. # More to the story? Goodchild argues that: >- *Variation* is more fundamental than *autocorrelation*. >- Without spatial variation there is only perfect autocorrelation. >- Maybe *variation* needs to be the real First Law? >- Doesn't discount role of correlation, just puts them in order. # Spatial autocorrelation + variation in the real world {.imgslide .r-fit-text} Measles cases in Texarkana, Tex and Texarkana, Ark in 1970 # What is smoothing?

Smoothing lets us separate signal from noise.

# What are some examples of epidemiological signals? >- Causal relationship between a risk factor and an outcome. >- Trend in a time series >- Disease hotspot in a spatial dataset. # What are some sources of noise we might encounter in epidemiological data? >- Random variation, i.e. process noise. >- Observation error. >- Exposure misclassification. # A hands-on example

Smoothing!
